participants.participant: Thomas J. Szkutak, Senior Vice President and Chief Financial Officer

plist.p: Thank you for standing by. Good day, everyone and welcome to the Amazon.com Third Quarter 2009 Financial Results Teleconference. At this time all participants are in a listen-only mode. After the presentation, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. Today's call is being recorded. For opening remarks and introductions I would like to turn the call over to Vice President of Investor Relations, Mr. Rob Eldridge. Please go ahead.
Hello, and welcome to our Q3 2009 Financial Results Conference Call. Joining us today is Tom Szkutak, our CFO.

The following discussion and responses to your questions reflect management's views as of today, October 22, 2009 only, and will include forward-looking statements. Actual results may differ materially. Additional information about factors that could potentially impact our financial results is included in today's press release and our filings with the SEC including our most recent annual report on Form 10-K. As you listen to today's call, we encourage you to have our press release in front of you which includes our financial results as well as metrics and commentary on the quarter. During the call, we will discuss certain non-GAAP financial measures. In our press release, slides accompanying this webcast, and our filings with the SEC, each of which is posted on our IR website, you will find additional disclosures regarding these non-GAAP measures including reconciliations of these measures with comparable GAAP measures. Finally, unless otherwise stated, all comparisons in this call will be against our results for the comparable period of 2008. With that, I'll turn the call over to Tom.

Thanks, Rob. I'll begin with comments on our financial results. Trailing 12 months free cash flow grew 98% to 1.92 billion dollars. Return on invested capital was 50%, up from 32%. ROIC is trailing 12 months free cash flow divided by average total assets minus current liabilities, excluding the current portion of long-term debt over five quarter ends. The combination of common stock and stock based awards outstanding was 451 million shares compared with 448 million. Worldwide revenue grew 28% to $5.45 billion or 29% excluding the $41 million unfavorable impact from year-over-year changes in foreign exchange rates. We're grateful to our customers who continue to take advantage of our low prices, vast selection, and free shipping offers including Amazon Prime.

Media revenue increased to $2.93 billion, up 17% or 18% excluding FX. EGM revenue increased to $2.36 billion, up 44% or 45% excluding FX. Worldwide EGM increased to 43% of worldwide sales up from 38%. Worldwide unit growth was 32%. Active customer accounts exceeded 98 million, up 17%. Worldwide active seller accounts were more than 1.8 million, up 24%. Seller units were 31% of total units. Worldwide gross profit was $1.27 billion, up 27%.

Now I'll discuss operating expenses excluding stock-based compensation. Fulfillment, marketing technology and content and G&A combined was $923 million, or 17% of sales, down 107 basis points year-over-year. Fulfillment was $444 million or 8.2% of revenue compared with 8.9%. Tech and content was $267 million or 4.9% of revenue compared with 5.3%. Marketing was $144 million or 2.6% of revenue, up from 2.5% in the prior year.

Now I'll talk about our segment results and consistent with the prior periods, we do not allocate to segments our stock-based compensation or other operating expense income net line item. In the North America segment, revenue grew 23% to $2.84 billion. Media revenue grew 13% to $1.41 billion. EGM revenue grew 36% to $1.29 billion, representing 45% of North America revenues up from 41%.

This week we started shipping Kindle with U.S. and international wireless and lowered its price to $259 from $279. This newest Kindle is available to ship to customers living outside the U.S. Customers in more than 100 countries around the world and U.S. customers traveling abroad can take advantage of Kindle 3G wireless technology to download a title in 60 seconds or less.

North America gross profit grew 28% to $752 million and gross margin increased 101 basis points to 26.5% driven by increases in other revenue in 3P product sales, improvements in inventory management including vendor pricing, partially offset by lower prices for our customers and changes in product mix.

North America segment operating income increased 77% to $156 million, a 5.5% operating margin. In the international segment, revenue grew 33% to $2.61 billion. Revenue growth was 35% adjusting for the $39 million year-over-year unfavorable foreign exchange impact during the quarter. Media revenue grew 22% to $1.52 billion and EGM revenue grew 54% to 1.06 billion or 58% excluding FX. EGM now represents 41% of international revenues up from 35%.

International gross profit grew 26% to $521 million or grew 30% excluding FX while gross margin decreased 108 basis points to 20%, driven by lower prices for our customers and changes in product mix partially offset by improvements in inventory management, including vendor pricing and increases in 3P product sales.

International segment operating income increased 36% to $194 million, a 7.4% operating margin. Excluding the unfavorable impact from foreign exchange rates, international segment operating income increased 44%. Consolidated segment operating income grew 52% to $350 million or 6.4% of revenue, up 101 basis points year-over-year. Excluding the $10 million unfavorable impact from FX, CSOI grew 56%. Unlike CSOI, our GAAP operating income includes stock-based compensation and other operating expense. GAAP operating income grew 62% to $251 million or 4.6% of net sales.
Our income tax expense was 60 million in Q3 or a 23% rate for the quarter. GAAP net income was $199 million or $0.45 per diluted share compared with $118 million in $0.27 per diluted share.

Turning to the balance sheet, cash and marketable securities increased $1.68 billion year-over-year to $4 billion. Our cash and marketable securities primarily consist of cash, government and government agency securities, AAA rated money market funds and other investment grade securities. Such amounts are recorded at fair value. Inventory increased 23% to $1.62 billion and inventory turns decreased to 12.1 from 12.4 a year ago as we expanded selection, improved in-stock levels, and introduced new product categories. Accounts payable increased 50% to $3.35 billion and accounts payable days increased to 72 from 63 in the prior year. Our investment in net fixed assets increased $355 million from a year ago to 1.09 billion. Our Q3 capital expenditures were $103 million.

I'll conclude my portion of today's call with guidance. Incorporated into our guidance are the order trends that we have seen to date and what we believe today to be an appropriately conservative assumptions. Our results are inherently unpredictable and may be materially affected by many factors including a high level of uncertainty surrounding exchange rate fluctuations as well as the global economy and consumer spending. It's not possible to accurately predict demand, and therefore our actual results could differ materially from our guidance.

As we describe in more detail in our public filings, issues such as settling intercompany balances and foreign currencies amongst our subsidiaries, unfavorable resolution of legal matters, and changes to our effective tax rate can all have a material effect on our guidance. Our guidance excludes the impact of Zappos including approximately $35 million of expenses related primarily to employee compensation costs, amortization of intangibles, and merger related expenses that would be recognized in the fourth quarter 2009 if the transaction closes as planned.

Guidance further assumes that we don't conclude any additional business acquisitions or investments, record any further revisions to stock-based compensation estimates, and that FX rates remain approximately where they have been recently. For Q4, we expect net sales of between $8.125 billion and $9.125 billion, or growth between 21 and 36%. This guidance anticipates approximately 500 basis points of positive impact from foreign exchange.

GAAP operating income to be between 300 and $425 million or grow between 10 and 56%. This includes approximately $100 million of stock-based compensation and amortization of intangible assets. We anticipate consolidated segment operating income which excludes stock-based compensation and other operating expense to be between 400 and $525 million or growth between 11 and 46%.

We remain heads down focused on driving a better customer experience through price, selection, and convenience. We believe putting customers first is the only reliable way to create lasting value for shareholders.
Thanks. With that, Rob, let's move to questions.
Great, thanks, Tom. Let's move on to the Q&A portion of the call. Operator, will you remind our listeners how to initiate a question?
Absolutely.
Our first question comes from James Mitchell from Goldman Sachs.

Great. Thank you very much for taking my question. It looks like you enjoyed very strong sequential North American revenue growth both media and EGM, much stronger in fact than you have enjoyed in previous third quarters. Could you talk about what drove that Q on Q growth in North American revenue?

Sure. If you take a look at – if you recall from 90 days ago, we did see a nice sequential increase, but as a reminder, Q2 we had a strong difficult compare from the previous year, Q2 of 2008. But even we still saw acceleration even if you look at Q1 of 2009 or Q4 of 2008. And it was very broad, you know, within the media categories. In fact, all the major categories within media saw an acceleration from Q2 to Q3. So it's very broad, and it was driven by a lot of the fundamentals. You know, having great low prices, certainly we had selection increases, in-stock increases during the quarter, as well as Prime is certainly having an impact. All of those things certainly had an impact. Also as a reminder, in North America as we finished Q3 of last year, certainly the last few weeks of the quarter were softer given what was going on economically. But again we saw very strong growth in the quarter.
Thank you.
We'll now go to Justin Post with Merrill Lynch.

Great, thank you. My question is on the margin outlook for the fourth quarter. We have heard some competitors out there getting more aggressive with price on books especially, but other areas. Maybe if you could characterize your view on the margin environment in the fourth quarter? And then secondly, on unearned revenue, it looked like it was up 197 million, a little less growth than in second quarter or in absolute dollars. Is that reflective at all of the Kindle, or are there other things in the unearned revenue line we should think about? Thank you.

In terms of your first question, what we anticipate will happen in Q4 was reflected in the guidance that we gave you. It's obviously challenging in any Q4 to give guidance, and given what's going on externally from a macro environment standpoint, it's certainly a challenging time to do so. But we still feel that being said, we still feel very good about what we're – what we saw in Q3, customers responding very positively, and right now we're heads down focused on making sure that we have a great customer experience during Q4.

Around the world right now, we're focused on making sure that we have great low prices, that we're getting our inventory, making sure that our in-stocks are where they need to be and selection on hand. You can see that our inventory did increase as it has in previous Q3s, and that's really getting ready for Q4. So we're optimistic, and we have given a wide range, given that optimism, and we're focused on customers. So again, hard to predict what will happen. But in terms of competitive environment, certainly it is very competitive. It's been very competitive since the day we launched, and we have many different competitors in all the different categories that we operate in around the world.
And then on unearned revenue, or, yeah, unearned revenue?

Certainly, there's a number of things that go into unearned revenue, and certainly we have some marketing relationships. Kindle goes in there, Prime goes in there. So, there's a number of things that are going in. It can be a little bit lumpy because of some of the things that go in, but certainly the principal pieces being that we've certainly talked about in the past being Kindle and Prime are doing very well, and we're very, very pleased with the growth that we're seeing in both of those, and we're excited with the announcement that we have related to Kindle that we can offer our newest Kindle at $259 effective today.
Thank you.
Our next question comes from Youssef Squali from Jefferies & Company.

Thank you very much. Tom, a couple quick ones. Would you consider opening up Kindle to supporting other formats considering the increase in availability of content from other providers? And related to that, is there a threshold above which you would start actually breaking out Kindle sales for us to gauge the level of your success? Thanks.

In terms of breaking out Kindle, certainly as you get to certain sizes, we've done in the past, we have broken out various countries, and we would follow whatever is required to do so. And obviously in the results that we give, we try to be as helpful as we can.

In terms of opening up Kindle, there's not a lot I can add to that. I wouldn't want to speculate what we might or might not do there. But we're focused on Kindle obviously making sure we offer great customer experience, and we're heads down focused on making sure that we do that.
Thanks.
We'll now go to Doug Anmuth from Barclays Capital.

Thanks for taking my question. Tom, two things. Can you talk about your profitability and the margins in particular came in at about 60 points I think above the high end of your range, so I'm just curious on what the biggest delta was on your results versus what you were expecting for the quarter there. And then secondly, it looks like your accounts payable days went to 72 which is a pretty significant increase. What were the key drivers in that? Thanks.

Sure. In terms of the margin, what you really are seeing, a number of factors, but certainly a principal one is you're seeing we had very strong growth. You're seeing very good leverage in our operating costs, and if you look at our gross margin was essentially flat year-over-year, and you saw good leverage in operating costs, and really across all of the key items. And so we had very good leverage. Certainly when you look at our operating costs, there's a variable component and there's also a fixed component, and so the fixed we're just seeing the largest leverage.

In terms of AP, we did see a very big increase. That's also reflected in the inventory that we brought in at the end of Q3 getting ready for the holidays. Keep in mind that when you compare that to last year at this time, there's a little bit of, you know, some seasonality, if you will, because if you recall, particularly in the U.S., we saw a little bit of a slowdown near the end of Q3, and so when that happens, and there was certainly uncertainty related to what was going on in Q4. You're seeing probably a little less replenishment than you would see given the results that you just saw in Q3. So part of that is certainly just more timing related as it relates to the two types of quarters that you're dealing with. There's also some mix of business there as well as some better terms with suppliers.
Thank you.
Our next question comes from Scott Devitt from Morgan Stanley.

Hi, thank you. Understanding there's been a unique volatility in business conditions and currency, when you gave the first quarter guidance, it was a range of 6 to 17 and you did 14, and then when you guided the second – the recent quarter, you gave 11 to 23 and did 28. So I was just wondering if you could comment on your visibility into 4Q given the still wide revenue range that you have given and the back-end loaded nature of the quarter and the way that it seems the business improved meaningfully throughout Q3 even after accounting for the September 15 event of last year? Thank you.

Sure. I think the only thing I could say is the – we're giving a wide range. The range is 21 to 36% growth on a dollar basis. We have reflected what exchange rates are recently, which is approximately 500 basis points of impact, which would be 16 to 21%. And that wide range reflects as I talked about a little bit earlier on the call, that uncertainty. That being said, we like what we saw in Q3, and as you also mentioned and heard in your question, it is a back-end loaded quarter. We have – it is very seasonal, and December is by far our largest month -- in terms of overall revenue, and so it's all in front of us. And so that's why for us right now, it's a very busy time as you can probably imagine, and we're focused very heavily on how do we make that experience as good as we possibly can for customers. And we try to give guidance that reflects very good growth for the quarter, but a wide range given the uncertainty.
Thank you.
Our next question comes from Jeetil Patel from Deutsche Bank Securities.

Hi, guys. Couple of questions. You have hit the two-year mark for Amazon Prime in Japan and almost in Europe. Are you seeing the same type of frequency lift you saw with Prime in the U.S. in terms of kind of magnitude of change in behavior? Second question, on FBA, are you seeing the ramp in FBA influence frequency as a whole in the business as you look at the U.S. market as you have better in-stock on products that are available from you guys?

Sure, Jeetil. It's Rob here. How are you doing? Consistent with what we have said, we're still very happy with the Prime programs worldwide. When we look at the international Prime programs not only in Japan, but also in Europe, you're seeing similarities in terms of subscriber growth as well as renewal rates, and across the geographies, Prime members tend to come to the site more often, shop with us more frequently, and also explore more of the different stores. And so you tend to see more cross shopping. So we're very, very happy with Amazon Prime across the globe.

In terms of FBA, we think it's a win for the sellers and we think it's a win for the customers, and so you saw on our results today that we still are seeing good growth with FBA programs here -- where we are in this period of time. So we're going to continue to put a lot of energy into both those programs for the benefit of our customers.
And are those influencing frequency or attach rates?
You're talking specifically about FBA?
Yes.

Again, I talk to, in the context of whenever you have the opportunity to deliver product to a customer with the United States a guaranteed two-day delivery or even faster, people are looking for express delivery, it's a positive thing for customers. So -
We'll now go to Gene Munster from Piper Jaffray.

Good afternoon. Just back on the margin side, some of the things you have been changing within the business model in terms of private labels and the product adds which conceptually carry a higher margin, is that starting to have an impact on margin or are they just too small to be adding up to anything?

We haven't broken out the impact of either of those two. But again in terms of private label, it certainly we certainly like that selection that we have, but it's still a relatively small part of our overall selection. And that is certainly something you can see just by browsing our website. You can look and so it's still a relatively small part of our selection.
Is there any growth in terms of the SKUs that you're having for private label that you can disclose?
No, no. We haven't – we're not breaking out any of the individual categories or also sales by vendor at all.
Thank you.
Our next question comes from Brian Pitz from UBS.

Thank you. Question on your shipping costs. If you look, you're up on shipping as a percentage of sales at about 6% in the quarter. That's the lowest we have seen in quite some time. Are you seeing much better shipping efficiencies, or is it really a function of higher digital media sales as part of that? Thanks.

Yeah, Brian, I think at the end of the day there's lots of factors that go into our shipping costs. And part of what I think you're seeing during the quarter is just we again saw good unit growth and we were able to leverage that sort of volume throughout the entire logistics chain.
Thanks.
Our next question comes from Heath Terry from FBR Capital Markets.

Great, thanks. Can you give us a sense of the traction that you're getting within the various components of Amazon Web Services and then just to what extent that business as a whole is contributing to the margin outperformance that we're seeing this quarter?
I'm sorry, I missed the first part of your question. It was about -

Sure, within Amazon Web Services, the individual services that are available within that, which ones are you seeing the most traction with that you're most kind of – or have the highest level of expectations for?

Yeah, it's similar to the rest of our business. We don't discuss the specific results of the different services, but we're seeing lots of demand around EC2 and S3 and SimpleDB. Developers use these services in different ways to create their own unique applications, and so we have a range of enterprise customers and startups, academic institutions who are using AWS for a diverse set of use cases and using these building blocks to create unique solutions. So I think it's very early with AWS, but we're very encouraged by the response that we're getting from our customer base. Right now we're going to continue to innovate on their behalf.

And I mentioned part of the margin, it's certainly part of – it would certainly be part of the other revenue increase, some of the things we talked about, including marketing, Amazon enterprise services, Web Services, those would be larger pieces of the other.
Great. Thank you.
We'll now go to Mark Mahaney from Citi.

Thanks. Two questions, please. The fulfillment leverage, I think that 8.1% as a percentage of revenue is the lowest you have ever had in the third quarter, so is there something that is sustainable there? Could you talk about whether that's a base to think about? I know there's seasonality in that line, but that seemed to strike us as a bit of an outlier.

And secondly, international, you're showing this accelerating international growth. Without the recession we probably would have seen it the last couple of quarters. Have you decided that from now on you're just going to ship your way to growth internationally? You don't need to expand beyond the countries that you're in? I only ask because you haven't expanded to a new international market with a base station there in about four years, but you seem to be doing fine without it, so is that the strategy from now on? Thanks a lot.

In terms of fulfillment, the operations team has done a great job in improving our overall efficiencies, and so you're certainly seeing that reflected in fulfillment. One reminder, as you look at fulfillment expense as a percentage of revenue versus last year, last year we had just opened up 3 FCs, and that's reflected in the Q3 balance of last year in terms of expenses.

In terms of international, no, you should expect to see that we will launch new geographies over time. What you're seeing reflected in the growth right now is some of the things I talked about earlier, but we have added a lot of selection. We've added a lot of new categories over the past couple years, and because of the opportunities we have in the existing countries that we operate in. So the team has done a great job in adding many new categories, adding selection within those categories, adding selection within the categories we're already in, making sure that we have great low prices, and executing operationally as well as certainly Prime is helping us internationally as well. So all of those are combining in the results that you see. But, no, you should expect to see more selection expansion going forward within the categories we're in as well as geographical expansion over time.
Thank you, Tom.
We'll now go to Jim Friedland from Cowen and Company.

Thanks. Question on, as long as we're on the topic of international, the Kindle going into international market, in terms of getting foreign language rights, what are the hurdles to achieving that, especially in your core international markets like Germany? What are the hurdles? What might be the timing to launch foreign language titles? Thanks.

Certainly it's an opportunity for us and not unlike we have very good relationships with a lot of the publishers and content owners in the geographies that we operate in, and certainly it's an opportunity for us over time to expand selection. Again, keep in mind from a Kindle perspective, our long-term vision is to have every title ever printed in any language available on Kindle in less than 60 seconds. It's certainly a big goal, and it's something the team is certainly working towards.
Okay. Thanks.
We'll now go to Ben Schachter from Broadpoint AmTech.

Last quarter you called out video games as impacting the quarter. I was wondering if you could update us on how that category impacted this quarter. And then also given the success of the Kindle, what are the types of the criteria you use to decide any other types of devices you might try to sell directly to consumers? Thanks.

In terms of video games, we're not breaking out any categories specifically this quarter, but what I would say is within media, we did see an acceleration in all of the key categories from Q2 to Q3. Speculation on any other devices, I wouldn't want to speculate what we might or might not do there.
We'll now go to Sandeep Aggarwal with Collins Stewart.

Thanks for taking my questions. Tom, can you talk about contribution from any one-time items in your media segment during the quarter, i.e. any popular gaming or books title or presale of Windows 7 contribution? And then second is on Kindle, can you talk about the linearity of the quarter? Did the lower price help you to hit maybe tipping point sooner?
I'm sorry, I missed the – in your first question, you asked for any one-time items in the growth that we saw -
In the media segment.
Sorry, was there more to it? I missed the last part of that first question. I apologize.

That's all right. Tom, so I – basically I wanted to know the contribution from one-time items in your media segment during the quarter such as presale of Windows 7 or any popular gaming title such as maybe Wii Sports Resort or any popular book titles.

Sure, we did see – it was a – we did see better releases than we've seen in previous quarters, particularly in the second half of the quarter, which is contributing to the growth that you see. But if you look at the growth from – that was essentially flat in Q2 to the 13% on a dollar basis or 14% on a local currency basis, the lion's share is not these – some of the new titles that were out there, but certainly contributed to the growth rate.
Our next question comes from Imran Khan from JPMorgan.

Yes, hi, thank you for taking my questions. Two quick housekeeping questions and one more of a big picture question. So in terms of the international gross margins, it seems like international gross margins are down 100 basis points on a year-over-year basis. Try to better understand what is driving that despite the growth in the third party business. And secondly user growth of 17%, active user growth, can you help me understand maybe is it more tilted toward international, or you're seeing broad based growth?

And more of a big picture question is regarding Web Services, it seems like talking to the developers that Amazon Web Services is getting a lot of credit. Can you give us some sense like what do you think is the gating factor that still only low single digit percentage of IT spending is cloud computing? Why it's not moving faster? Thank you.

In terms of international gross margins, the – one of the things certainly you're seeing is impacting it is lower prices to customers, changes in product mix. If you look at our EGM growth in Q3, it was up 58% on a local currency basis. That compares to 48% growth last year. International media was up 22% in the quarter, up 18% versus last year. So that mix of shift towards a higher percentage of EGM is certainly impacting gross margins in the quarter. That between lower prices and changes in mix was partially offset by improvements in 3P as well as vendor pricing and inventory management. So that's really what was impacting gross margins.

In terms of Web Services, we're very optimistic about Web Services. We have some great services that are getting some very good traction. It's very early, and the team has done a great job in terms of executing on those services and making those a reliable. They're very, it's great pricing on those services, and the team has continued to innovate in that space. So the team is very excited about it, and we like what we see there.
Great, thank you.
. We'll now take a question from Jeffrey Lindsay from Sanford Bernstein.

Hi, thank you for taking my questions. Will it be necessary as in previous years to significantly increase staffing for the holiday season, or do you think you're already happy with current staffing levels? And then just, could you just give us any kind of comment on how progress is going with Joyo Amazon given Turbo's recent claims to have 78% of e-commerce in China? Thank you.

In terms of staffing, every year we supplement our teams and our FTs around the world with additional staffing, and this year will be no different. And we've continued to add some capacity particularly in international recently to get ready to serve customers.

In terms of Joyo, we're not breaking out in terms of giving any statistics on any of the growth in each of the geographies today, but in terms of how we feel about Joyo, we think our business in China is very good. We have a very good team there. Their focus is consistent with other geographies in trying to make sure that we have good customer experience, and it's a great – we think that China is a great long-term opportunity, and the team is working very hard on behalf of customers.
Thank you.
Our next question comes from Spencer Wang from Credit Suisse.

Thanks. Good afternoon. Tom, maybe I was wondering given how much free cash flow you guys are generating, if you could just update us on your thoughts in terms of uses of cash and maybe how acquisitions fit into that and how you maybe think about whether to build versus buy when you think about product category expansion? Thanks.

Sure. In terms of uses of cash, we have – I wouldn't speculate what we might do, except for we still have an authorization for share repurchases that there is 900 million remaining on the authorization, so certainly that would be part of -- potentially part of our plans.

When you think of acquisitions, we look at those opportunistically. It's not something new. We have been looking at acquisitions for a number of years now, and when we find ones that we like; we've done some to enter new geographies over time. We've done some where we think speed to market is important. We have done some where we like the team that has a very specific skill set. So there's a number of different types of ones that we have done, and there's not much I can add to that. We'll continue our focus there like we have over the past years, and as there's opportunities, we'll certainly look at what makes sense.
Thanks.
Our next question comes from Brian Nagel from Oppenheimer.

Hi, good afternoon. My question, I wanted to focus on the book category. Obviously a lot of press lately about new pricing strategies. The question would be, as we think about our models, both from sales, and maybe even a margin perspective, near and longer term, how should we think about some of the changes that have been made in book pricing lately?
I'm sorry, could you repeat the second half of that question?
I'm sorry. I was just saying as we think about our models, particularly in sales growth or in margins in books, how could the recent actions on book pricing affect those numbers?

I apologize. We haven't broken out the growth rates or the margins of the book category. It's included. The books margins would be included in our North American gross margins for those sales in North America and corresponding ones in international.

I think the way you should think about any of our categories is that we operate in competitive environments, and that's something that has existed since the day we opened our doors. And from our perspective, we're going to continue to focus on what is right for customers and -- as I've mention a number of times on this call, and that's in all of our categories and all of our geographies, and so those are things because it's important to customers.

In terms of also when you talk about margins, one thing that we clearly do is our focus is on, primary measure is free cash flow and free cash flow per share, and so we focus on those operating profit dollars and free cash flow dollars and not individual margins.
Thank you.
And our final question will come from Aaron Kessler from Kaufman.

Hi, guys. A couple questions. First, any update on Checkout by Amazon? Clearly there could be some resistant from some pure play competitors expanding outside of the core retail market. And I'm not sure if you commented, but U.S. other revenues is up about 20% sequentially. I just wanted to see if you had an explanation for the strong growth in that category. Thanks.

Yeah, Checkout by Amazon, you know, it's very, very early, and the team is doing a good job there. But it's very early, and we think it's a nice opportunity, and the team is executing well there, but again it's very early for us.

In terms of other, beyond what we have said already, I don't have a lot to add there. Certainly the pieces that roll into there are our Web Services business, which is getting good traction, our cobranded credit card arrangements. We have some promotional and marketing revenues, and then Amazon enterprise services. So those are the make-up of other and what's reflected in the growth that you're seeing there. We do have, some of that revenue is promotional in nature or marketing in nature, and can tend to be as you have seen in some quarters a little bit lumpy. And so that's the only I guess color I could add to it.
Great. Finally on tax rate, any guidance for Q4? It's been jumping around somewhat this year.
No, the – if you look at our year to date tax rate adjusted for any larger items would reflect our best estimate for the year at this stage.
Great. Thank you.

Great. Well, thank you for joining us on the call today and for your questions. A replay will be available on our IR website at least through the quarter. We appreciate your interest and we look forward to talking with you again next quarter.
This concludes today's presentation. Thank you for your participation.
